text.text:
You’ve probably noticed this matcha stuff knocking about for a while now, with many a cafe frothing up medium-to-bad versions of the green stuff. It's not brand new by any stretch - Japanese monks have been drinking it for centuries - but recently London's matcha intake seems to have quadrupled, and we wanna know why. What are the health benefits? Does it actually taste good? How does it compare to green tea? ...So many question knocking about our tired January brains.

So we asked the team over at Tombo (a Japanese cafe whose business now covers three London sites and counting) to see if they had any insights. These guys import premium matcha directly from Japan, so they should know their stuff.

To understand what the big deal is (and why it costs £3.90 a cup) we started with lil science lesson. Made from the same plant as green tea, and black tea for that matter, matcha is shade-grown for the last three weeks before harvest, forcing the leaves to produce more chlorophyll, making them greener and sweeter.

The leaves are then carefully hand-picked, steamed and ground. That whole rigmarole means you get more goodness in your cup (apparently the nutrients of 10 cups of infused green tea).

Maya from Tombo explains how matcha provides a more steady energy boost than coffee and how it's full of vitamins and nutrients like vit C, E, B2, folic acid and beta carotene. There's also rumours of mood-calming, concentration-enhancing, AND metabolism-boosting properties; plus some nitty gritty about antioxidants and anti-carcinogens that we don't feel qualified to explain, never mind prove. 

We're no scientists, but these all sound like properties we'd like in all beverages. And if it's good enough for the Zen Buddhist monks who invented the stuff back in the 1190s to aid meditation, it’s good enough for us.

Being the upstanding, thorough types that we are, we tested a matcha tea, a latte and a flat green with varying degrees of punch. The flavour is slightly earthier and sweeter than your average green tea, and not as bitter (especially if you pour in boiling water and leave it too long, like we've apparently been doing).

Next we tucked into some pretty desserts, but they were a little hit-and-miss. A purple potato and matcha roll cake provided little excitement for us, the matcha tart offered some, but the soft serve ice cream blew us away. In fact, we'd go for another right now.

Hard to say how it made us feel, though as promised there were no jitters. We felt neither more awake nor more asleep which probably means it worked its mixture of calming and mood-enhancing magic - or we fell hook line and sinker for the spiel.

Either way we left happy with a particular fondness for that superb matcha soft serve - in its frozen, creamy form the delicate earthy flavours really shine through. We're not sure we're ready to fully commit to matcha life, but for those looking to cut down on coffee, cut up on vitamins, or just add a little ‘wellness’ to their Instagram feed, this could be just the new leaf to turn over.

tip.text:
Healthy lifestyle is central to this Japanese cafe and matcha bar, run by mother and son team Manami and Louis. After realising good quality Japanese food was always mega spenny in London, they decided to bring us a little taste of the action, with premium products at more reasonable price points.

Get involved with colourful and wholesome bento boxes, sushi bowls, rice bowls and comforting curry bowls - we had a katsu number that really took the edge off. And then there's the green stuff, the whole reason you're here: matcha. Made with premium leaves, grown in the shade, hand-picked and ground whole - there's all sorts of health benefits stuffed into this one, along with a subtle sweet taste. Whether you go for a matcha shot (the most traditional serving), a tea or latte, you're sure to get that caffeine kick without any of the jitters of coffee. This lot have won awards for specialising in the above, so you're truly in very safe hands.

It's also mixed into tarts, cakes, shakes and brownies, as well as a perfectly balanced soft serve. Sweet and bitter in all the right places, we couldn't get enough.

Once upon a time (the year was 2011), hidden behind a secret doorway in a residential neighbourhood in Tokyo, a high-quality, high-design coffee stall opened up. Taking inspo from the Japanese tea ceremony this cute little cubic bar featured one barista who would serve up careful coffees focusing on the calm ritual of brewing.

Now dotted about all over the globe Omotesando Koffee stalls are laying on drip filter coffees, cappuccinos, matcha lattes and delish' sweet pastry kashis. If you want a slice of that Insta-friendly action, the Rathbone Square development in Fitzrovia is where you need to be.

This Japanese bakery and café is all clean lines, neat and tidy, with a perfectly presented selection of patisseries. Pop in for a coffee and have a peruse of the eye opening selection of bakes. Choosing really is tricky with all sorts of tarts, buns and cakes on offer. Try a simple matcha roll or go big with a 'choux trios', which looks like three joined up profiteroles filled with whipped sesame, matcha and azuki custard.

If you're after something savoury there's a banging selection of breads and sarnies too - chicken katsu sandos, pumpkin rolls, curry buns or the amazing egg mayo bun - it's curry-flavoured dough filled with egg mayo, coated in breadcrumbs and cornflakes and deep fried - wowza.

The Japan Centre sells all manner of Japanese fare - from fresh produce, squidgy mochi balls and matcha cakes to dried mushrooms and packet noodles. It's like a Japanese Whole Foods - but real suave.

When we heard they were opening a depachika (basement food hall) we got all hot under the collar. It's a biggie, with space for 100 backsides in the centre surrounded by open kitchens. Cruise through specialist sake, tea and miso rooms and - if you're feeling super keen - check out the demonstration kitchen. Or go for the more laid back approach of sidling up to a stall, ordering something random, and slurping it up in confused joy. Between us we covered sushi, katsu curry, tonkotsu ramen, tempura udon and sukiyaki beef. But the real winner was the takoyaki with bonito - octopus balls with those sensual undulating fish flakes.

If you like crepes and cream, it wouldn't be a wild stretch of the imagination to think you might enjoy a mille crepe. Made up of layer upon layer of paper thin crepes in between French crème patissière. As this bakery's name would suggest it specialises in these sweet towers, which come in a number of flavours: original, chocolate, lemon, earl grey, matcha, sesame and more. These guys are real big on quality ingredients, buying the good stuff and preparing all sorts in-house: their Sicilian lemons are very much juiced by hand and the chocolate is that 70% refined shit.

Decor of this teeny tiny shop is just as pretty as the cakes, with white and pastel colours a'plenty. Sadly you can't eat those custard-coloured walls, though they are good for cake selfies - if that's your scene.

Take away only.

Shibuya is a café-cum-bakery-cum-bar-cum-sushi joint. Breathe. Decor-wise it's all clean lines, pale wood and calm Japanese feels. You might want to go for warming curries like their ton katsu with a deep fried pork cutlet or the black cod marinated in miso paste. There's also a pretty good sake selection to be drunk neat or mixed into the likes of a sparkling sake cocktail.

When we're about, we only have eyes for the desserts though - we're partial to a matcha roll cake or the impressive looking bingsu. It's basically a huge tower of shaved ice (made of condensed milk) covered in more goodies - like oreos, strawberries and mango. We like ours topped with sweet red beans and matcha which adds a little tang. They even give you an extra little pot of condensed milk, in case you're not sweet enough. Happy days.
